greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of distinct zeros of x^2-x-1 mod prime(n).
comment: For the prime modulus 5, the polynomial can be factored as (x+2)^2, showing that x=3 is a zero of multiplicity 2. The discriminant of the polynomial is 5. Also note how this sequence is related to the Fibonacci sequence A051830; for n>3, a(n) = 2*A051830(n). - _T. D. Noe_, Aug 13 2004
link: J.-P. Serre, On a theorem of Jordan, Bull. Amer. Math. Soc., 40 (No. 4, 2003), 429-440, see p. 433.
mathematica: Table[p=Prime[n]; cnt=0; Do[If[Mod[x^2-x-1, p]==0, cnt++ ], {x, 0, p-1}]; cnt, {n, 105}] (* _T. D. Noe_, Sep 24 2003 *)
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Sep 23 2003
ext: Corrected and extended by _T. D. Noe_, Sep 24 2003
